subject: Re: [junit] Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: Jason: Thanks for your reply. As you have mentioned in your reply, we need to write a getCount() mthod to get the value of the counter . We do not want to do
messageBody:
Jason: Thanks for your reply. As you have mentioned in
your reply, we need to write a getCount() mthod to get
the value of the "counter". We do not want to do this.
Without "GET" method, is there any way we can get the
value of the "counter".
Thanks
Balakrishnan
================
public void testIncrementBy() {
> Counter counter = new Counter();
> assertEquals("initial value", 0,
> counter.getCount());
>
> counter.incrementBy(5);
> assertEquals("incremented value", 5,
> counter.getCount());

--- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 12:58, balakrishnan sengodan
> wrote:
> > With out using GET method, how do we test the
> method
> > that does not return value. Please give me an
> example.
>
> First of all, there is a wealth of knowledge to be
> found in the
> archives. You should try looking there before
> posting.
>
> A 'void' method should have some discernable effect
> on the system,
> right? Test the effect.
>
> public class Counter {
> .
> .
> .
> public void incrementBy(int count) {
> this.counter += count;
> }
> .
> .
> .
> }
>
> public class CounterTest extends TestCase {
> .
> .
> .
> public void testIncrementBy() {
> Counter counter = new Counter();
> assertEquals("initial value", 0,
> counter.getCount());
>
> counter.incrementBy(5);
> assertEquals("incremented value", 5,
> counter.getCount());
> }
> .
> .
> .
> }
>
> =jason
>
>
